description: From medical Latin fōmes (“fomite”), a figurative extension of its original sense of kindling, tinder, &c. Gradually supplanted in use by fomite, a mistaken backformation of its plural form fomites, from Latin fōmitēs.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, medicine) The morbid matter created by a disease.
examples: If this putrid ferment could be more immediately corrected, a stop would probably be put to the flux, and the fomes of the disease likewise removed.

entries.meaning: (archaic, medicine) Synonym of fomite: a substance able to communicate infection between people.
examples: I cannot say that I have known it spread from fomites.

entries.meaning: (archaic, figurative) Anything which similarly facilitates the spread of something similarly deleterious.
examples: Naturall tempers... prove a great Fomes of sinne.
